workflow.name: Realtime Notion Todoist 2-way Sync with Redis
workflow.description:
## Purpose

This solution enables you to manage all your Notion and Todoist tasks from different workspaces as well as your calendar events in a single place.

All tasks can be managed in Todoist and additionally Fantastical can be used to manage scheduled tasks & events all together.

## Demo & Explanation

[![demo video](https://img.youtube.com/vi/k66j6ZspjCg/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/k66j6ZspjCg)

## How it works

- The realtime sync consists of two workflows, both triggered by a registered webhook from either Notion or Todoist
- To avoid overwrites by lately arriving webhook calls, every time the current task is retrieved from both sides.
- Redis is used to prevent from endless loops, since an update in one system triggers another webhook call again. Using the ID of the task, the trigger is being locked down for 15 seconds.
- Depending on the detected changes, the other side is updated accordingly.
Generally Notion is treaded as the main source. Using an "Obsolete" Status, it is guaranteed, that tasks never get deleted entirely by accident.
- The Todoist ID is stored in the Notion task, so they stay linked together
- An additional full sync workflow daily fixes inconsistencies, if any of them occurred, since webhooks cannot be trusted entirely.
- Since Todoist requires a more complex setup, a tiny workflow helps with activating the webhook.
- Another tiny workflow helps generating a global config, which is used by all workflows for mapping purposes.

## Mapping (Notion >> Todoist)

- Name: Task Name
- Priority: Priority (1: do first, 2: urgent, 3: important, 4: unset)
- Due: Date
- Status: Section (Done: completed, Obsolete: deleted)
- <page_link>: Description (read-only)
- Todoist ID: <task_id>

## Current limitations

- Changes on the same task cannot be made simultaneously in both systems within a 15-20 second time frame
- Subtasks are not linked automatically to their parent yet
- Recurring tasks are not supported yet
- Tasks names do not support URL’s yet

## Prerequisites

### Notion
- A database must already exist (get a basic template [here](https://steadfast-banjo-d1f.notion.site/17682b476c848086b002de766879aa71)) with the following properties (case matters!):
  - Text: "Name"
  - Status: "Status", containing at least the options "Backlog", "In progress", "Done", "Obsolete"
  - Select: "Priority", containing the options "do first", "urgent", "important"
  - Date: "Due"
  - Checkbox: "Focus"
  - Text: "Todoist ID"
### Todoist
- A project must already exist with the same sections like defined as Status in Notion (except Done and Obsolete)
### Redis
- Create a [Free Redis Cloud](https://redis.io/try-free/) instance or self-host


## Setup

[![setup video](https://img.youtube.com/vi/73jhyU0t4c4/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/73jhyU0t4c4)

*The setup involves quite a lot of steps, yet many of them can be automated for business internal purposes.*

Just follow the video or do the following steps:
- Setup credentials for Notion (access token), Todoist (access token) and Redis - you can also create empty credentials and populate these later during further setup
- Clone this workflow by clicking the "Use workflow" button and then choosing your n8n instance - otherwise you need to map the credentials of many nodes.
- Follow the instructions described within the bundle of sticky notes on the top left of the workflow


## How to use

- You can apply changes (create, update, delete) to tasks both in Notion and Todoist which then get synced over within a couple of seconds (this is handled by the differential realtime sync)
- The daily running full sync, resolves possible discrepancies in Todoist and sends a summary via email, if anything needed to be updated. In case that contains an unintended change, you can jump to the Task from the email directly to fix it manually.

parameters.formDescription: This tool gathers all necessary information and builds a JSON config which is needed as globals in the sync workflows.

parameters.content:
## Keep in sync
if you update the mapping, make sure to change it in the other node as well!

## Keep in sync
if you update the mapping, make sure to change it in the other node as well!

## Set Globals
Use Sync Setup Helper Workflow to generate the JSON and paste it in every Globals Nodes

Update section for each task in Todoist using the Sync API in full sync mode. Use batching and split into multiple batches, if needed, since there is a request limit of 100 full syncs within a 15 minute period.
# Unidirectional sync from Notion to Todoist
Get open/incomplete tasks from both Notion and Todoist
Generate an email report containing all changes made by this workflow, since changes in Todoist are being overwritten.

## Trigger based synchronization from Todoist to Notion (part of bi-directional sync)

**Delete the task** if it does not fit into the filter anymore
**Update the task** if it needs to be changed
Notion tries to deliver webhooks again. To ensure the data is up to date, the payload must be retrieved again.

## Set Globals
Use Sync Setup Helper Workflow to generate the JSON and paste it in every Globals Nodes
Continues on error, so it is not necessary to retrieve task beforehand
Following nodes reference to this node, so the trigger can easily be replaced
Store relevant information in highlighted execution data, in case of debugging
Store more information, which was not available earlier
Instead of deleting pages in Notion, it is a safer practice to mark them as obsolete instead.
In rare cases Notion fires multiple webhooks within a short period of time, when creating a new task. This prevents the creation of duplicates in Todoist.
The mapping is more advanced and also includes fall-back values for edge-cases
Checking for a cached flag in Redis, to prevent overrides and endless loops.
# Trigger based synchronization from Notion to Todoist (part of bi-directional sync)

## Configure Webhook
Grab the webhook URL and use it in the Notion automation. If using the NotionWebhookEmulator instead, replace this node with the nodes shown below.
Only sync focussed & planned tasks for efficiency reasons
The mapping between the Notion and Todoist tasks is stored in Notion
The Todoist ID is being cached in Redis for 15 seconds, so the other Diff sync does not get triggered.
**Create task** if it does not exist (anymore)
Edge case: the task has been moved from Obsolete to Done

## Todoist Webhook Router Example (optional)
Since Todoist sends the updates of all projects to a single webhook, the requests need to be routed accordingly.
To do so, create a separate workflow, each containing the flow above, except replace the webhook and switch nodes with an "Execute Workflow Trigger".
Then activate the nodes below and configure it, so it calls the sub-workflows accordingly.
Using the event type from Todoist is the only option to actually recognize, if a task was deleted
The mapping is more advanced and also includes fall-back values for edge-cases
Previous node always returns output data, since it uses a filter to retrieve a matching item
Reverse mapping the Section/Status
Update section for in Todoist using the Sync API in full sync mode (**maximum of 100 requests within a 15 minute period!**)
Store more information, which was not available earlier
The Notion ID is being cached in Redis for 15 seconds, so the other Diff sync does not get triggered.
**Delete Notion page** if Todoist task has been deleted
Store more information, which was not available earlier

Handle tasks **only found in Notion**. This can still mean, that the task exists in Todoist, but does not match the filter, since it has been completed. In that case the Todoist task is being retrieved. If it exist, the Todoist Task will be reopened, otherwise it will be created.
The Todoist ID is being cached in Redis for 15 seconds, so the Diff sync does not get triggered.

Handle tasks which show **differences** between both systems. If there are differences, the Todoist task will be overwritten by all properties from Notion. Also the status is being updated in the following step accordingly.
The Todoist ID is being cached in Redis for 15 seconds, so the Diff sync does not get triggered.

Handle tasks **only found in Todoist**. This can still mean, that the task exists in Notion, but does not match the filter, since it has been completed. In that case the Notion page is being retrieved. If it does not exist, because it was deleted, the Todoist Task will be deleted as well.
The Todoist ID is being cached in Redis for 15 seconds, so the Diff sync does not get triggered.

## Set Schedule
Set the preferred period. Usually once a day, likely outside working hours should be a solid option.
Preparing data for comparing

## Set mail address
Provide the email address where the report should be sent to. This node can also be replaced by an SMTP or similar node.

If consuming data from the Notion Webhook Emulator instead of a regular Notion Webhook, the data is structured differently and can contain multiple items. This section makes the workflow compatible with both approaches.

## Register Webhook in Todoist App
Grab the URL from here and add it to the Todosit developer app as described in the setup instructions

## Set project ID and name
The ID can be copied from JSON in Globals Node.
If syncing multiple Todoist projects, use the router described below.

### Replace trigger
Use this trigger in the sub-workflows instead

### Register Webhook
Configure this webhook in the Todoist App as mentioned above

### Set project IDs and names
Copy each project ID from the JSON of the different Globals Nodes and name the branches by the projects.

### Select sub-workflows
Choose the sub-workflows based on the branch of the Switch Node

# 0. Start here
### Notion
- A database must already exist (get a basic template [here](https://steadfast-banjo-d1f.notion.site/17682b476c848086b002de766879aa71)) with the following properties (case matters!):
  - Text: "Name"
  - Status: "Status", containing at least the options "Backlog", "In progress", "Done", "Obsolete"
  - Select: "Priority", containing the options "do first", "urgent", "important"
  - Date: "Due"
  - Checkbox: "Focus"
  - Text: "Todoist ID"
### Todoist
- A project must already exist with the same sections like defined as Status in Notion (except Done and Obsolete)
### Redis
- Create a [Free Redis Cloud](https://redis.io/try-free/) instance or self-host
### Setup credentials in n8n
- Notion: https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/notion/
- Todoist: https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/todoist/
- Redis: https://docs.n8n.io/integrations/builtin/credentials/redis/
### Clone workflow
- Clone this workflow into your n8n environment and map the credentials (beware, Todoist credentials are also used in HTTP request nodes)
- Check for every yellow sticky notes. They show instructions which need to be done once

# 1. Generate config JSON for Globals Nodes
The sync workflows have a Node named "Globals", which contain mapping information for both Notion and Todoist. This flow helps to generate the config, using a multi-form.
### How to use
- Check if the credentials in the Notion and HTTP Request Nodes are set correctly
- Activate this workflow
- Open production URL of the form trigger and complete the form
- Copy the resulting JSON code into all 3 "Globals" nodes

# 2. Setup Todoist Webhook
- In the Todoist App open Settings > Integrations > Developer > Build Integrations
- Click "Create a new app"
  - App name: "Notion-Todoist Sync" / Name of your n8n instance
  - App service URL: (leave empty)
- Click "Create app"
- Update settings of the app:
  - OAuth redirect URL: Grab the production URL of the "OAuth redirect" Node (from step 3 on the right)
- Click on "Save settings", leave tab open

- Activate this workflow
- Open the Production URL of the "Todoist Webhook Setup Helper" Node (from step 3 on the right)
- Copy the Client ID and secret from the App settings into the form and submit it
- When prompted for permissions, click on "Agree"

- Go back to App settings tab
- Scroll further down to "Webhook"
- Update settings of the app:
  - Webhook callback URL: Grab the production URL of the "Todoist Webhook" Node (Todoist to Notion Diff sync)
  - Select these options:
    - item:added
    - item:updated
    - item:completed
    - item:uncompleted
    - item:deleted
- Click "Save webhook configuration"
- Click "Activate webhook"
- Settings can now be closed

# 4. Setup Notion Webhook
You can choose from two options and also choose different options for different workspaces, e.g. optionA for a business related workspace and option B for a private workspace. Both options work similarly, option A is a bit easier to setup, yet it is more expensive.

## Option A: Notion Webhook via Automation (paid plan required)
- Create a new [automation](https://www.notion.com/help/database-automations) on the database which should be synced
- Rename the automation to "Notion-Todoist Sync" or similar
- Add trigger: "Any property edited"
- Add action: "Send webhook"
  - URL: Grab the production URL from the "Notion Webhook" Node of this workflow (Notion to Todoist Diff sync)
  - Content: Select all existing properties
- Click "Save"

## Option B: Notion Webhook Emulator (no subscription required)
- Follow the instructions here: https://n8n.io/workflows/2284-provide-real-time-updates-for-notion-databases-via-webhooks-with-supabase/
- Use the Webhook URL from the "Notion Webhook" Node of this workflow to push the updates to

# 3. Activate Todoist Webhook
Webhooks are a bit different in Todoist then usual. A Developer App needs to be created and once be connected to via OAuth, to activate the webhook functionality.
This flow only works when using the **production URL** of it's form trigger.

conditions.leftValue: ={{ $if($('Map Todoist to Notion1').item.json.due !== null, $('Map Todoist to Notion1').item.json.due.toDateTime().toISO(), null) }}

parameters.content:
Retrieve Todoist task, which can be completed or deleted at this point.
Using advanced retry logic, since the "Get many tasks" endpoint does not return completed tasks.

Todoist webhooks can arrive late. To ensure the data is up to date, the payload must be retrieved again. Triggers on deletion can overlap, thus try 3 times, then just stop.
Using advanced retry logic, since the "Get many tasks" endpoint does not return completed tasks.
No more retries needed, if Task does not exist.
Overwrite description with Notion URL
Copy task description initially to Notion, before it get's replaced in Todoist by the Notion URL

# 5. Finishing Touches

### Cleanup
Now technically everything is ready, but it is missing better usability and maintainability. So start by moving (cut & paste) the 3 big flows (outlined in blue) to separate n8n workflows. You can name them as follows:
- Notion-Todoist Full Sync (<workspace-name>)
- Notion-Todoist Diff Sync (<workspace-name>)
- Todoist-Notion Diff Sync (<workspace-name>)
 
Make sure to **activate every workflow** which requires it.
Also save this workflow to avoid duplicates.

### First run
- Execute the **Notion-Todoist Full Sync** workflow manually first
- Now that the initial sync is done and you can start using the realtime sync

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.

data.details: The Execute Workflow node can be used when you want your workflow to treat another workflow as a step in your flow. It allows you to modularize your workflows and have a single source of truth for series of actions you perform often.

data.details: The Crypto node allows you to hash and Hmac string in a specified format and sign a string using a private key. Use this node when you want to encrypt your data.

data.details: The Filter node can be used to filter items based on a condition. If the condition is met, the item will be passed on to the next node. If the condition is not met, the item will be omitted. Conditions can be combined together by AND(meet all conditions), or OR(meet at least one condition).
